2.34 p.m.

MAIN ESTIMATES, 1961 (Cont.)


    Head 56 -

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday just before the House adjourned, we were discussing the duties of Inspectors of Schools. The Minister, in his reply, stated that the primary role of Inspectors of Schools was to inspect schools in order to advise and assist them. I was very glad to be able to agree wholeheartedly with him on that. Unfortunately, Sir, in the carrying out of the policy and in the working out of the details, things have gone amiss. I drew his attention to one main function that has been added on, that is, to investigate into complaints sent in by writers of anonymous letters. I felt, Sir, that the procedure was wrong, that the anonymous letters should have been put into the wastepaper basket or sent to the Ministry of Home Affairs for further investigation. Or if any action was needed, such letters should have been sent to the heads of schools in order not to give the impression that the Ministry assumes, on the basis of these complaints, that the heads and the teachers have to prove their innocence.

    Sir, just after the school closed for the vacation, a 13-page circular was sent out-

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Thirteen - or was it 20?

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: The first circular was 13 pages. There was an additional second circular. Principals of all Government and aided schools were asked to attend to the list of instructions so that they could become effective from 1st January, 1961. Sir, perhaps the people in the Ministry do not realise that even heads of schools are human beings, and if it is a school vacation after a six-day week, surely they are entitled to some vacation, although we all know that in most cases, heads of

Column: 581

schools do not have much rest even during vacation, because they have to clear up arrears of work and prepare for the coming term.

    Sir, this circular illustrates the widening gulf that is now taking place, separating the Ministry officials from the principals and the teachers in the various schools. Certain relationships are developing which are not desirable. Those in the Ministry somehow act as if they belong to the ruling class, and those in the schools feel that they belong to the subject working class.

    I would like to read out a few extracts to illustrate my point.

    `School Tuck-shop Committee

    Every Government and aided school which has a tuck-shop shall set up a school tuck-shop committee comprising the following:-

    Principal of school, Chairman;

    a representative of the teachers of the school;

    a representative of the hawkers of the school;

    an Inspector of Schools from the Ministry of Education;

    a representative of students for a secondary or a full school; and

    a representative of either old boys or parents or pupils for a primary school.

The School Tuck-shop Committee shall meet at least twice a year. Other meetings should however be held as and where necessary.'

    The Chairman: Order. I am just wondering whether this is not a matter of general policy of the Ministry which ought to be debated when we come to the last amendment. So far the item pinpointed is the item in connection with Inspectors of Schools, and they, I take it, perform duties laid down by the Ministry. If it is part of their duty merely to send a notice of this nature to headmasters, then I suppose they are just carrying out the policy of the Ministry. So that perhaps we are getting away from the motion before the House, and that is, an amendment in connection with Inspectors of Schools only.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Sir, my point here is that if Inspectors of Schools have to be involved in these duties, they will not be able to carry out their duties as Inspectors of Schools. It is not in

Column: 582

connection with their duties as Inspectors of Schools in this particular case-

    The Chairman: Order. In that event, I suppose the hon. Member has made his point. But if he goes into detail about what a headmaster has to do about tuckshops, then I think perhaps he is going a little further and dealing with the policy of the Ministry in connection with tuckshops.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Sir, I would like to prove here that in the procedure adopted by Inspectors of Schools towards teachers and principals, their approach is wrong. It is pertinent to the duties of Inspectors of Schools, not the policy of the Ministry, I think, Sir.

    The Chairman: Order. Is the Member then alleging that the contents of that circular in regard to tuckshops were prepared by the Inspectors of Schools, as part of their duties, and that the contents of the circular have not had the general approval of the Ministry, and, therefore, do not represent the policy of the Ministry? Is that the allegation?

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: I do not think that the Minister is aware that the approach and all the instructions are going against the Ministerial policy, and that if they were carried out, then the Inspectors of Schools could not carry out their proper duties as Inspectors of Schools if they become inspectors of tuckshops.

    The Chairman: Order. Perhaps the Minister will be able to assist us on this point; whether the contents of this circular about tuckshops represent Ministerial policy.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to the alleged circular, I am glad the Member for Tanglin has since corrected his statement. I think last evening he said it was a 20-page circular. This afternoon he has corrected his statement and said that it was a 13-page circular. This circular was issued with my approval. In fact, soon after we came into office, it was important-

Column: 583



    The Chairman: Order. That is exactly what I wish to know. I think it is now quite clear that that is the general policy of the Government in the Ministry of Education. Therefore, I think, in fairness to the other Members who have in fact given notice of amendments, this matter of the tuckshop ought to be discussed when we come to the final amendment. It is, of course, a question of time available, and I am trying to be fair to the other Members who have given notices of amendments.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Sir, then I will proceed to the other answers given by the Minister. He says applicants for the 20 posts are available but it takes time to get them approved. We have noticed that there seems to be more red-tape developing in the Ministry, and it is more difficult to get approval for appointments of teachers and clerks than previously. I do not know where the fault is, because the Minister himself now complains that he is facing the same difficulty -that there is difficulty in getting approval of appointments to the posts of Inspectors of Schools.

2.45 p.m.

    Sir, therefore, he had to resort to the appointment of heads of schools as acting Inspectors of Schools. Sir, the result of that has been that heads of schools have been pulled out of their schools to perform duties in the Ministry as Inspectors of Schools, to the neglect of their own duties in the schools. No doubt, senior assistants were appointed in the schools to carry out the functions of the heads, but since the senior assistants are not given any responsibility allowance, one cannot expect them to carry out all their responsibilities fully, because if anything goes wrong they have to take the blame. So usually when it comes to important issues, they will wait for the head, who is now working in the Ministry, to come along and carry the baby himself. Also, Sir, in the matter of pay, if a major in an army is asked to do the duty of a colonel, he is given an acting allowance. But if he is made to do that duty for months, Sir, surely something must be done to speed up

Column: 584

things and reduce the red tape in the Ministry.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, arising out of what the Minister said yesterday, if I understood him aright, he said that applications to fill up the vacancies in these posts were sent to the P.S.C. in June and July this year. If that is correct, it is now nearly six months since the applications were sent. It disclosed a very unsatisfactory state of affairs in so far as staffing is concerned in the Education Ministry.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Leong Keng Seng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Member for Tanglin said something regarding the matter of principals. We know that the Member for Tanglin has always been a principal. What he has said is for the benefit of principals. He does not pay attention to and has no regard for the interests of the parents, students and-

    The Chairman: I do not know how those preliminary remarks have any relevance at all to the question raised by the Member for Tanglin. Let us come to the point of Inspectors of Schools.

    Mr Leong Keng Seng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as regards the Inspectors of Schools, we know that in the past, the relevant department was in the hands of the old officials. It was not taken proper care of by the Government. After our new Government came into office, we have had to make some adjustments. We had to transfer some people to the Inspectorate. When these Inspectors go out to inspect the schools, of course, this will directly affect the interests of the principals. Those principals who in the past had been irresponsible and corrupted, of course, would not like this. They wanted to carry on their old attitude under the old Government. Of course, we do not say that all the principals are like this. There are also many responsible principals. When our school inspectors go to visit the schools, they gather many valuable views from the parents and the students. Since the Government took office, we have established a Complaints Branch,

Column: 585

and under its direction we have dealt with many cases of complaints. Some of the complaints were signed and some were not. Of those that were unsigned, we cannot, of course, say that they had all been fabricated. Of these unsigned complaints, at least more than 50 per cent of them were true. Because it was a rule that when there were complaints the complainants must go through the principals, it was therefore difficult for them to go direct to the Ministry of Education to make their complaints. We handed these over to the Inspectors to investigate. It is but right and proper because the job of the Inspectors is to investigate the relevant matters and to see that the schools are properly carried on.

    I have some examples here. Last year, there were three primary school principals who pocketed money from the sale of books and building funds. They were properly dealt with after being called up by the Inspectors. Another primary school principal had, under the old Government, fabricated a diploma to the effect that he was a University graduate. So after due investigation, he was also properly dealt with. Another example was of a primary school principal who signed the form of a teacher saying that this particular teacher was properly qualified, when it was not so. This case was investigated by an Inspector and the teacher was also properly dealt with. Another case was this. A middle school principal appointed his own relative to an important post in his school and also to control the management of the school.

    Without these investigations by Inspectors, how could we have found out all these anomalies in the schools? The Member for Tanglin must know that we must accept the criticisms of parents, students and the public. If the principals have done no wrong, then, of course, they will not incur any criticism from anybody. We know of a Chinese saying which says, "True gold will not dread fire." So if principals carry out their functions properly, they will have no fear at all. I am only mentioning a few examples here. I believe most principals are very responsible people and are seriously carrying

Column: 586

out their jobs. I think only a few of them have had complaints made against them by the people because they had already been corrupted under the old Government. But then the Government in those days had not carried out their responsibility of investigating all these cases. Since the new Government took office, it has started on a new line. Of course, there are many people who do not feel satisfied. I think all the Inspectors have properly carried out their responsibilities.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education seems to have misunderstood my argument in that he thought that I was firstly criticizing the appointments of Inspectors of Schools. Sir, I have said that I agree completely with the Minister regarding the primary role of Inspectors of Schools. But what the Parliamentary Secretary has said has now confirmed that although the Minister considers the primary role of Inspectors of Schools is to inspect and advise and assist, it has now become their primary role to inspect and seek evidence to incriminate and to punish.

    Sir, rarely have I heard of Inspectors of Schools nowadays coming with this question, "Have you got any complaints? Is there anything where we can help?" Sir, that is the primary role of Inspectors of Schools, or should be. I hope you will pardon me, Sir, for having to explain in answer to what I have been accused of, that I have always been a principal. Sir, for nearly 31 years I was a teacher. I began my teaching profession as a teacher in a primary school.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Member for Tanglin inquired as to the duties of Inspectors of Schools in the Ministry of Education, I did say that the primary function of Inspectors would be to advise on organisation and administration of schools; to ensure that syllabuses are being complied with, also, of course, when it comes to a teacher crossing the bar, they will drop in to see whether he should be recommended to cross the bar, and so forth. But I did add that there

Column: 587

were other multifarious duties, not, of course, being able to anticipate what the Member for Tanglin would want to proceed thereafter. But the multifarious duties would include investigation where complaints have been lodged. Unfortunately, the Member for Tanglin keeps insisting as if the only function of the Ministry of Education or even the Inspectorate is just in pursuance of complaints. It is part and parcel of a change of government that there would be a reorganisation, not only in the Ministry of Education, but in other Ministries. Therefore, letters of complaints are addressed to the Ministry, and sometimes personally to the Minister himself. Well, anyone who has not done any wrong should not be afraid of any complaint, whether it is anonymous or a signed letter of complaint, because it can be safely assumed that if action is to be taken, the party who is aggrieved would be given a chance to say something for himself, and I can put it to the Member for Tanglin, Sir, to provide any evidence that harsh treatment had been meted out to any particular teacher or principal. In fact, I can truthfully say, Sir, that after investigations have been made, I do not remember a single instance in which I have rejected the professional advice that has been offered by the Inspectors of Schools themselves.

[Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr G. Kandasamy) in the Chair]


3.00 p.m.

    If it is a complaint of a nature which affects a principal of a school, I invite him to have a chat to discuss the mater. At first, some principals took it as if it was going to be a black mark against them, and they hurriedly tendered their resignations. I think the Member for Tanglin will be able to find out that some of them have since regretted their move or have withdrawn their resignations. Because all that was required was to say to them, "Look here, there is now a complete change in government. It is the people's Government." The Minister is not sitting in an office segregated from the people. He is

Column: 588

an Assemblyman who has to face the public at least once a week when he goes down to his constituency - like last night I did not come back to my home till midnight in order to meet the people in my constituency to try and solve their problems as an Assemblyman. We listen to their problems and try to do what we can, not just on educational matters but on matters embracing citizenship and on other matters which for some reason or other they feel they have to see their Assemblyman. Of course, we get verbal complaints, "So and so is a wicked man. So and so is a wicked teacher." But I am never prepared to work on verbal complaints. If they have a complaint, they are expected to put it down in writing. These complaints can be put into two categories. When complaints are received by me, I send them to the Chief Inspector of Schools with this comment, "Please investigate, or please deal."

    Sir, I must say that the Member for Tanglin has been somewhat erratic in trying to infer as if the Inspectors of Schools in the Ministry of Education are such wicked people. After all, most of them, including those who have been seconded to the Ministry, have been teachers themselves with as many years of experience as the Member for Tanglin. They have also been principals. I am confident that when these officials proceed with the investigations they know exactly how to talk to the principal or to the teacher, and how to conduct the investigations to the best of their ability. Therefore, I must say that if the Member for Tanglin is able to give me evidence and tell me exactly which particular official has been lacking in courtesy or in finesse, I will be the first to take it up with the official concerned, not to punish him but to advise him that times have changed and that they have got to go to the schools to find out for themselves whether the complaints stated are true and, if so, what they can suggest should be done in the circumstances.

Column: 589



    Last evening, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Member for Tanglin suggested that he heard it said that complaints had to be investigated within 48 hours. I must say that this statement is completely untrue. My colleague, the Parliamentary Secretary, has already explained how, as a result of complaints, we have been able to follow up to put right serious discrepancies: for example, unauthorised collections, false certificates, and so forth. Some complaints were in respect of reports that principals or teachers were doing additional work, perhaps as pianists in night clubs. Now there is a ruling in the Ministry that the principals or teachers concerned could apply for permission to undertake additional employment not exceeding six hours per week, and the Ministry of Education very rarely turn down such applications. But if the teachers concerned, knowing of the existence of such a circular, do not ask for permission, then I think they are not being fair. If a teacher, who should be conscientious and fair to his students, accepts employment as a pianist in a night club, he has got to be told, "Are you going to be fair to the children at school?" If he thinks that he is a very good pianist in a night club, then perhaps he should be a full-time performer and withdraw from the teaching service. There are other teachers who give private tuition on the sly. Here again, we do not object to a teacher wanting to give private tuition within limits, but his first duty is to the school and to the Ministry which give him a good living wage.

    Of course, we also have complaints about the immoral conduct of certain teachers which extends even to the islands. It is not for me to investigate into the private life of an individual teacher, but it interests me, as a Minister, if his moral conduct affects his teaching or if he is guilty of such conduct as to be a danger to the morals of young children. Only then should an investigation be carried out and adequate justice meted out.

    As a result of the courses which were conducted in the Political Study Centre

Column: 590

for principals of schools and in my discussions with them, I was a little surprised that principals were not quite aware of their rights and responsibilities. In fact, some principals appear' not to have any sense of discretion. That was a very unfortunate impression I gained and, therefore, I decided that our Inspectors should get to know more about the principals of schools. So during the third term of this year, that is to say, during the last few months, I gave instructions that Inspectors of Schools should meet principals in their various groups once a term. This has already taken place, not due to the Member for Tanglin taking up the case on behalf of the principals, but because this is a matter which has already exercised the minds of the Inspectorate. I read the minutes of these meetings and I think the tone has considerably improved vis-a-vis the principals and the inspectors.

    Talking on this subject of principals, you will remember, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, that the Member for Tanglin asserted that he very bravely defied certain requests of the Ministry to call there to collect documents and cheques. This is exactly a case where if a principal of a school is that fearful he should not be a principal. After all, a principal is paid a charge and responsibility allowance. Far from the principal becoming a peon and a messenger boy collecting documents and cheques from the Ministry, what does the Member for Tanglin expect the Ministry to do? Does he expect the Ministry to write to the messenger boy of the Anglo-Chinese School - for example - to come to collect certificates, cheques, and so forth? Naturally, the letter must be addressed from either the Director of Education or the Accountant of the Ministry to the principal, who is the officer responsible for the administration of his school, and it is up to him to decide. If it were a case of, say, examinations where secrecy is important, then the principal himself should call at the Ministry for the question papers to be taken by him personally - that is, if the memorandum does suggest that the principal should personally call at the Ministry. But if

Column: 591

stereotyped letters are sent to him saying, "Please call at the Finance Section with this chit to collect a cheque in respect of this or that", or, "Would you please call at the Establishment Section when you next visit the Ministry?" - mind the word "please"; we are being very courteous - or, "Whenever you call at this Ministry, would you please see the Office Superintendent and collect certificates, etc.?", therefore whether he is to be a peon or a principal depends upon himself. So the Member for Tanglin has not been a very brave man when he said that he defied the Ministry of Education circular and sent somebody else, because most principals have done that.

    The Member for Tanglin brought up the subject of asking for permission to leave the State. Surely, that is normal procedure.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Johore Bahru.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I myself go to Johore Bahru for satay. I do not ask permission for that. Surely this is a question of discretion on the part of an individual. It is not a question of principle. If a person chooses to be so literal about a circular or an instruction, I am sorry for him.

    Coming to the question of the bulky circular for tuckshops - 20 pages reduced to 13 pages within 24 hours - this is another case where Members of the Opposition always overstate their case and then decide to check up and get cold feet, resulting in the circular shrinking to 13 pages. This circular is actually six pages of contents and six pages of appendices. This is actually a consolidation of previous circulars. It is not something entirely new which is being sprung on principals. All that it tries to effect are standard rates of tuckshop fees which, on the whole, have been reduced after the experience of one year based on profit and not on arbitrary charges. The number of stall-holders allowed in each tuckshop is clearly defined. Also limitation in the range of food to be sold by a stall-holder and a specimen application form.

Column: 592



    I am, however, a little disappointed in the Member for Tanglin when he suggested, "Are not principals expected to have their holidays?" Of course! I am one of those who believe in compulsory leave, and I think it is good for any individual in service to have his leave - of course, at the right time. The circular that went round to principals of schools was dated 6th December, 1960. Everybody knows that the next school year begins on 3rd January, 1961. Well, we would like to see that all tuckshops and stall-holders get things started properly for the full year. So a circular went out suggesting that principals of English schools should meet on the 12th December - that is, more or less a week later - those of Chinese schools on the 14th (that is, today) and those of Malay schools on the 16th, to explain, if necessary, anything in the circular which may not be quite clear. As explained earlier, the circulars have to be addressed to principals and there is this sentence which says, "Please send your senior assistant to the meeting if you are unable to attend." Surely somebody responsible must turn up to be able to interpret the instructions, to ask questions, and be assured about the contents of the circular.

3.15 p.m.

    As regards the acting allowances for officers seconded to the Ministry, it is true that in the past there had been considerable frustration because officers who were performing the duties of officers with higher responsibilities were known as officiating and not acting. I think that has been put right. We have recommended that all officers who were seconded or have been acting in certain capacities would draw acting allowances.

    Lastly, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Member for Cairnhill suggested that because the names of principals or senior teachers who have applied for appointments as Inspectors were sent to the Public Service Commission in June and July, therefore, the position in the Ministry is unsatisfactory. It is not exactly unsatisfactory. The staffing position remains like this: they are already doing the job in an acting capacity as seconded members of the staff.

Column: 593

Whether they will be permanent holders would depend upon the decision of the Public Service Commission.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Kandasamy, Sir, I am afraid the Minister has got me wrong. I did not say that it was unsatisfactory - the fact that these people kept on acting. I said that the applications were sent in June and July, and surely some decision should have been made by the Public Service Commission after a lapse of six months. If no decision had been made, the position therefore must be unsatisfactory vis-a-vis the Public Service Commission.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Surely, Mr Deputy Speaker, we are not talking about the Public Service Commission. We are talking about the Ministry of Education.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, would the Minister not consider it unsatisfactory that applications were sent in June or July and that nothing definite has been done about it? Is this not making things difficult for his Ministry? Fortunately for him, he has people acting. If he had nobody acting, and suppose he wanted new teachers - and it would take six months for the Public Service Commission to recommend appointments for the thousands of teachers who have to come into the service next year - would that not be unsatisfactory to the Department?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not here to defend the Public Service Commission. It may happen that the particulars that have been forwarded to the Public Service Commission have been vetted, and they have had to be pushed back for further queries, and that is where the ding-dong takes some time. That is as far as I can really say.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Kandasamy, Sir, I am glad to hear the Hon, the Minister for Education say that principals are expected to exercise discretion, because this is something that has not been made clear in the past. It all depends on how far the principal is allowed to exercise discretion. I remember being told by a very senior officer

Column: 594

in the Department, who is still there, that when circulars are sent round, every principal or person concerned must first put them into practice. Whether he or she objects to them or thinks that they are wrong, they must be put into practice first, and then the complaint or argument about it could be made to the Ministry. And probably there was some sense in the argument when he said, "Can you imagine. Mrs Seow, if a circular goes out and the Ministry is not able to say that that circular will be implemented by everyone? That the Ministry has to guess how many principals might think it is good or how many principals might think it is bad and should not be implemented? It has been shown to me, and insistence has been made, that the circulars must be implemented first. Then any complaints or opinions as to the circulars not being workable should come later." Therefore, I would be grateful to the Minister if he could make it very clear whether that is not so or whether principals can exercise discretion. Even on little things like this: sometime ago a principal sent a circular round the school saying, "Please send your record books to the office." Unfortunately it happened to be a European principal.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: When was that?

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Sometime ago, but it just - [Interruption].
